Line 79: Line 79:
These tools provide automated checks for common packaging mistakes in both binary and source packages, including Debian policy violations and potential compatibility problems.
These tools provide automated checks for common packaging mistakes in both binary and source packages, including Debian policy violations and potential compatibility problems.
â
While a maintainer typically aims to correct all issues pointed out by <code>lintian</code> and <code>linda</code>, different distributions can have different policies regarding them. For example, [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]] requires all packages originating in Ubuntu to be clean, but a for a package merged into Ubuntu from Debian, there is no such requirement: new changes should simply not introduce any warnings in addition to existing ones. This is done to minimize the divergence between Debian and Ubuntu packages.
+
While a maintainer typically aims to correct all issues pointed out by <code>lintian</code> and <code>linda</code>, different distributions can have different policies regarding them. For example, [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] requires all packages originating in Ubuntu to be clean, but a for a package merged into Ubuntu from Debian, there is no such requirement: new changes should simply not introduce any warnings in addition to existing ones. This is done to minimize the divergence between Debian and Ubuntu packages.
